title: The point of GG?
body: It seems completely meaningless to say gg at the end of a game to me, I feel like it should be reserved for those actually good games because let's face most of the time the game wasn't really good someone dc'd or fed/trolled etc. I just feel like saying gg every time you finish a game regardless of whether it was makes the it lose it's meaning.

replies.body: Saying "GG" has essentially lost its status as an acronym for "good game" and is now a virtual handshake whereby you thank your opponents for the game.
Or it's said by your team-mates after you've died for the tenth time.

It's good sportsmanship.

It doesn't matter if it was the worst game of all time, you're expected to respect your opponent.

You know how they shake hands at the end of a pro game? That's where they say gg. That's what it's all about.

Think of it this way,

Bowing/handshake/exchange words/whatever, whether before or after a competition/fighting to the death/again whatever was something people will only do out of respect for the opponent.

However since it was used so much it simply becomes a formality like saying "Thank you" now.

On the other hand, it's thankfully not anywhere as strict as Thank You where people actually expect it coming out of your mouth otherwise oh boy how rude of you, "gg" remains as a side thing people either give/take or otherwise and no harms done.

Ofc people use it as an attempt to be sarcastic or demeaning more than delivering respect to the game these days which is sad to see aye. 

Personally though I try to use "gg" as close to how it was supposed to be, I only type it after a game that I actually enjoyed. But as it turns out they are for the most part, the games I have won. I am such a d1ck yer.
